get.description:
Intrusion Detection System (IDS) monitors the network for the presence of unauthorized APs
and clients, and detect rogue APs, interfering APs, and other devices that can potentially
disrupt network operations. It also logs information about the unauthorized APs and clients,
and generates reports based on the logged information.
Intrusion Protection System (IPS) protects networks according to planned policies when the
specfic attacks happen.

This feature is only applicable on AP.

delete_object_type.name: object_type
delete_object_type.description: LOCAL - To delete local objects. SHARED - To delete shared objects. Default - Defaults to SHARED if not provided

delete_scope_id.name: scope_id
delete_scope_id.description: Scope at which local object needs to be deleted. Mandatory if object_type = LOCAL. Should not be provided for object_type = SHARED.

delete_persona.name: persona
delete_persona.description: Persona for which the local object needs to be deleted. Mandatory if object_type = LOCAL. Should not be provided for object_type = SHARED.

post_object_type.name: object_type
post_object_type.description: LOCAL - To create local objects. SHARED - To create shared objects. Default - Defaults to SHARED if not provided

post_scope_id.name: scope_id
post_scope_id.description: Scope at which local object needs to be created. Mandatory if object_type = LOCAL. Should not be provided for object_type = SHARED.

post_persona.name: persona
post_persona.description: Persona for which the local object needs to be created. Mandatory if object_type = LOCAL. Should not be provided for object_type = SHARED.

patch_object_type.name: object_type
patch_object_type.description: LOCAL - To update local objects. SHARED - To update shared objects. Default - Defaults to SHARED if not provided

patch_scope_id.name: scope_id
patch_scope_id.description: Scope at which local object needs to be updated. Mandatory if object_type = LOCAL. Should not be provided for object_type = SHARED.

patch_persona.name: persona
patch_persona.description: Persona for which the local object needs to be updated. Mandatory if object_type = LOCAL. Should not be provided for object_type = SHARED.

get_object_type.name: object_type
get_object_type.description: Retrieves LOCAL or SHARED or both(default) configuration objects.

get_scope_id.name: scope_id
get_scope_id.description: Configuration at a given scope. Mandatory for view_type = LOCAL.

get_persona.name: persona
get_persona.description: Filters configuration specific to given persona type. If not provided and view_type = LOCAL, then defaults to all persona.

effective.name: effective
effective.description: True - Returns effective configuration (i.e hierarchically merged configuration). False - Returns committed configuration at a given scope.

detailed.name: detailed
detailed.description: True - Includes annotations in the returned json to indicate the type of object, scope, and persona. False - Returns only config objects without annotations.

view_type.name: view_type
view_type.description: LIBRARY - Returns shared objects in library. For LIBRARY, all other parameters listed below, except 'detailed' , will be ignored. LOCAL - Returns configurations for a scope and one or more persona based on parameters below.

schema.description: The number of requests left for the time window.

X-RateLimit-Remaining.description: The number of requests left for the time window.

schema.description: The UTC date/time at which the current rate limit window resets.

X-RateLimit-Reset.description: The UTC date/time at which the current rate limit window resets.

ArubaIds_IdsSchema.description:
Intrusion Detection System (IDS) monitors the network for the presence of unauthorized APs
and clients, and detect rogue APs, interfering APs, and other devices that can potentially
disrupt network operations. It also logs information about the unauthorized APs and clients,
and generates reports based on the logged information.
Intrusion Protection System (IPS) protects networks according to planned policies when the
specfic attacks happen.

This feature is only applicable on AP.

profile.description:
Intrusion Detection System (IDS) monitors the network for the presence of unauthorized APs
and clients, and detect rogue APs, interfering APs, and other devices that can potentially

and generates reports based on the logged information.
Intrusion Protection System (IPS) protects networks according to planned policies when the

ANY.description: Any of local or shared config object.

detection-protection.description:
Intrusion Detection/Pretection System offers a wide selection of intrusion detection and
protection features to protect the network against wireless threats. The following policies
can be configured:
1. Infrastructure Detection Policies — Specifies the policy for detecting wireless attacks
   on access points.
2. Client Detection Policies — Specifies the policy for detecting wireless attacks on clients.
3. Infrastructure Protection Policies — Specifies the policy for protecting access points
   from wireless attacks.
4. Client Protection Policies — Specifies the policy for protecting clients from wireless attacks.
5. Containment Methods— Prevents unauthorized stations from connecting to network.

x-enumDescriptions.LOW:
Low client detection level, it enables:
Detect valid client misassociation.
x-enumDescriptions.MEDIUM:
Medium client detection level, it enables:
Detect Disconnect Station Attack
Detect Omerta Attack
Detect FATA-Jack Attack
Detect Block ACK DOS
Detect Hotspotter Attack
Detect unencrypted valid client
Detect Power Save DOS Attack.
x-enumDescriptions.HIGH:
High client detection level, it enables:
Detect EAP rate anomaly
Detect rate anomaly
Detect Chop Chop Attack
Detect TKIP Replay Attack
IDS signature—Air Jack
IDS signature—ASLEAP
Detect ghost tunnel client attack
NOTE: Higher detection levels include the detection policies of the levels below them.
x-enumDescriptions.VALID_CLIENTMISASSOCIATION: Detection of misassociation between a valid client and an unsafe AP.
x-enumDescriptions.OMERTA_ATTACK:
Detect Omerta attack. Omerta is a DoS attack tool based on the 802.11 protocol.
It sends disassociation frames to disassociate clients.
x-enumDescriptions.FATAJACK:
Detect of fatajack attacks. FATA-Jack is an 802.11 client DoS tool that tries to
disconnect targeted stations using spoofed authentication frames that contain an
invalid authentication algorithm number.
x-enumDescriptions.BLOCK_ACK_ATTACK: Detection of attempts to reset traffic receive windows using the forged Block ACK Add messages.
x-enumDescriptions.HOTSPOTTER_ATTACK:
Detection of hotspotter attacks. The Hotspotter attack is an evil-twin attack which
attempts to lure a client to a malicious AP.
x-enumDescriptions.UNENCRYPTED_VALID:
Detection of unencrypted valid clients. An authorized (valid) client that is passing
traffic in unencrypted mode is a security risk. An intruder can sniff unencrypted traffic
(also known as packet capture) with software tools known as sniffers.
x-enumDescriptions.POWER_SAVE_DOS_ATTACK:
Detection of Power Save DoS attack. To save on power, wireless clients will sleep periodically,
during which they cannot transmit or receive. A client indicates its intention to sleep by
sending frames to the AP with the Power Management bit ON. The AP then begins buffering traffic
bound for that client until it indicates that it is awake. An intruder could exploit this mechanism
by sending (spoofed) frames to the AP on behalf of the client to trick the AP into believing
the client is asleep. This will cause the AP to buffer most, if not all, frames destined for the client.
x-enumDescriptions.EAP_RATE_ANOMALY:
Use EAP handshake analysis to detect an abnormal number of authentication procedures
on a channel and generate an alarm when this condition is detected.
x-enumDescriptions.RATE_ANOMALIES:
Detection of rate anomalies. Many DoS attacks flood an AP or multiple APs with 802.11
management frames. These can include authenticate/associate frames which are designed to
fill up the association table of an AP. Other management frame floods, such as probe request
floods, can consume excess processing power on the AP.
x-enumDescriptions.CHOPCHOP_ATTACK:
Detection of ChopChop attack. ChopChop is a plaintext recovery attack against WEP encrypted
networks. It works by forcing the plaintext, one byte at a time, by truncating a captured frame
and then trying all 256 possible values for the last byte with a corrected CRC. The correct guess
causes the AP to retransmit the frame. When that happens, the frame is truncated again.
x-enumDescriptions.TKIP_REPLAY_ATTACK:
Detection of TKIP replay attack. TKIP is vulnerable to replay (via WMM/QoS) and plaintext
discovery (via ChopChop). This affects all WPA-TKIP usage. By replaying a captured TKIP data
frame on other QoS queues, an attacker can manipulate the RC4 data and checksum to derive the
plaintext at a rate of one byte per minute.
x-enumDescriptions.SIGNATURE_AIRJACK:
Signature matching for the AirJack frame type. AirJack is a suite of device drivers for 802.11(a/b/g)
raw frame injection and reception. It was intended to be used as a development tool for all 802.11
applications that need to access the raw protocol, however one of the tools included allowed users
to force off all users on an AP.
x-enumDescriptions.SIGNATURE_ASLEAP:
Signature matching for the ASLEAP frame type. ASLEAP is a tool created for Linux systems
which is used to attack Cisco LEAP authentication protocol.
x-enumDescriptions.WPA_FT_ATTACK:
Detection of WPA FT attacks. If a vulnerable AP is attacked through the 802.11r FT handshake,
then AP-to-client traffic can be attacked.
x-enumDescriptions.GHOSTTUNNEL_CLIENT_ATTACK:
Ghost tunnel client side attack detection. A ghost tunnel attack uses 802.11 probe request
packets or beacon packets to communicate with the host and need not establish a Wi-Fi connection.
For the client-side ghost tunnel attack, the AP monitors the abnormal probe request packets in
the wireless environment. When a client is heard by the AP, it looks for abnormal probe request
packets from the client.

items.description:
Specifies the policy for detecting wireless attacks on clients.
Each of options contains several default levels that enable different sets of policies.
An administrator can customize enable or disable these options accordingly.

x-enumDescriptions.LOW:
Low client protection level, it includes:
 Detect AP Spoofing
 Detect Windows bridge
 IDS signature—deauthentication broadcast
 IDS signature—deassociation broadcast.
x-enumDescriptions.MEDIUM:
Medium client protection level, it includes:
Protect Valid Station.
x-enumDescriptions.HIGH:
High client protection level, it includes:
Protect Windows Bridge
NOTE: Higher protection levels include the protection policies of the levels below them.
x-enumDescriptions.VALID_STA: Protection of valid stations. When enabled, valid stations are not allowed to connect to an invalid AP.
x-enumDescriptions.WINDOWS_BRIDGE: Protecting from a Windows Bridge involves containing the client that is forming the bridge so that it can not connect to the AP.

items.description:
Specifies the policy for protecting clients from wireless attacks.
Each of these options contains several default levels that enable different sets of policies.
An administrator can customize enable or disable these options accordingly.

x-enumDescriptions.LOW:
Low infrastructure detection level, it includes:
 Detect AP Spoofing
 Detect Windows bridge
 IDS signature—deauthentication broadcast
 IDS signature—deassociation broadcast.
x-enumDescriptions.MEDIUM:
Medium infrastructure detection level, it includes:
Detect ad hoc networks using VALID SSID—Valid SSID list is autoconfigured based on the AP configuration
Detect malformed frame—large duration.
x-enumDescriptions.HIGH:
High infrastructure detection level, it includes:
Detect AP impersonation
Detect ad hoc networks
Detect valid SSID misuse
Detect wireless bridge
Detect 802.11 40 MHz intolerance settings
Detect active 802.11n greenfield mode
Detect AP flood attack
Detect client flood attack
Detect bad WEP
Detect CTS rate anomaly
Detect RTS rate anomaly
Detect invalid address combination
Detect malformed frame—HT IE
Detect malformed frame—association request
Detect malformed frame—auth
Detect overflow IE
Detect overflow EAPOL key
Detect beacon wrong channel
Detect devices with invalid MAC OUI
Detect ghost tunnel server attack
NOTE: Higher detection levels include the detection policies of the levels below them.
x-enumDescriptions.AP_SPOOFING:
AP Spoofing detection. An AP Spoofing attack involves an intruder sending forged frames
that are made to look like they are from a legitimate AP. It is trivial for an attacker
to do this, since tools are readily available to inject wireless frames with any MAC address
that the user desires. Spoofing frames from a legitimate AP is the foundation of many wireless attacks.
x-enumDescriptions.WINDOWS_BRIDGE:
Detection of Windows station bridging. A Windows Bridge occurs when a client that is associated
to an AP is also connected to the wired network, and has enabled bridging between these two interfaces.
x-enumDescriptions.SIGNATURE_DEAUTH_BROADCAST:
Signature matching for the deauth broadcast frame type. A deauthentication broadcast attempts
to disconnect all stations in range. Rather than sending a spoofed deauth to a specific MAC address,
this attack sends the frame to a broadcast address.
x-enumDescriptions.SIGNATURE_DEASSOCIATION_BROADCAST:
Signature matching for the deassociation broadcast frame type. By sending disassociation frames
to the broadcast address (FF:FF:FF:FF:FF:FF), an attacker can disconnect all stations on a network
for a widespread DoS.
x-enumDescriptions.ADHOC_USING_VALID_SSID: Detection of ad hoc networks using valid or protected SSIDs.
x-enumDescriptions.MALFORMED_LARGE_DURATION:
Detection of unusually large durations in frames. The virtual carrier-sense attack is implemented
by modifying the 802.11 MAC layer implementation to allow random duration values to be sent
periodically. This attack can be carried out on the ACK, data, RTS, and CTS frame types by using
large duration values. This attack can prevent channel access to legitimate users.
x-enumDescriptions.AP_IMPERSONATION:
Detection of AP impersonation. In an AP impersonation attacks,
the attacker sets up an AP that assumes the BSSID and ESSID of a valid
AP or a neighboring AP. The AP impersonation attacks can be done for
man-in-the-middle attacks, a rogue APs attempting to bypass detection, or a honeypot attack.
x-enumDescriptions.VALID_SSID_MISUSE: Detection of interfering or Neighbor APs using valid or protected SSIDs.
x-enumDescriptions.WIRELESS_BRIDGE:
Enables detection of wireless bridging. Wireless bridges are normally used to connect multiple
buildings together. However, an attacker could place (or have an authorized person place) a
wireless bridge inside the network that would extend the corporate network somewhere outside
the building.
x-enumDescriptions.HT_40MHZ_INTOLERANCE:
Detection of 802.11n 40 MHz intolerance setting, which controls whether stations
and APs advertising 40 MHz intolerance will be reported.
x-enumDescriptions.HT_GREENFIELD:
Detection of HT devices advertising greenfield preamble capability. When 802.11 devices use
the HT operating mode, they can not share the same channel as 802.11a/b/g stations. Not only
can they not communicate with legacy devices, the way they use the transmission medium is
different, which would cause collisions, errors, and retransmissions.
x-enumDescriptions.AP_FLOOD:
Detection of flooding with fake AP beacons to confuse the legitimate users and to
increase the amount of processing needed on client operating systems.
x-enumDescriptions.BAD_WEP:
Detection of WEP initialization vectors that are known to be
weak or repeating. A primary means of cracking WEP keys is to capture 802.11
frames over an extended period of time and search for implementations that are
still used by many legacy devices.
x-enumDescriptions.CTS_RATE_ANOMALY:
Detection of CTS rate anomaly. The RF medium can be reserved via Virtual Carrier Sensing
using a CTS transaction. The transmitter station sends a RTS frame to the receiver station.
The receiver station responds with a CTS frame. All other stations that receive these CTS
frames will refrain from transmitting over the wireless medium for an amount of time specified
in the duration fields of these frames.
Attackers can exploit the Virtual Carrier Sensing mechanism to launch a DoS attack on the
WLAN by transmitting numerous RTS and/or CTS frames. This causes other stations in the WLAN
to defer transmission to the wireless medium. The attacker can essentially block the authorized
stations in the WLAN with this attack.
x-enumDescriptions.RTS_RATE_ANOMALY:
Detection of RTS rate anomaly. The RF medium can be reserved via Virtual Carrier Sensing using
an RTS transaction. The transmitter station sends a RTS frame to the receiver station. The
receiver station responds with a CTS frame. All other stations that receive these RTS frames
will refrain from transmitting over the wireless medium for an amount of time specified in the
duration fields of these frames.
Attackers can exploit the Virtual Carrier Sensing mechanism to launch a DoS attack on the WLAN
by transmitting numerous RTS and/or CTS frames. This causes other stations in the WLAN to defer
transmission to the wireless medium. The attacker can essentially block the authorized stations
in the WLAN with this attack.
x-enumDescriptions.INVALID_ADDRESSCOMBINATION:
Detection of invalid address combinations. In this case, an intruder can cause an AP to transmit
deauthentication and disassociation frames to all of its clients. Triggers that can cause this
condition include the use of broadcast or multicast MAC address in the source address field.
x-enumDescriptions.MALFORMED_HTIE:
Detection of malformed HT information elements. The IEEE 802.11n HT IE is used to convey
information about the 802.11n network. An 802.11 management frame containing a malformed
HT IE can crash some client implementations, potentially representing an exploitable condition
when transmitted by a malicious attacker.
x-enumDescriptions.MALFORMED_ASSOC_REQ:
Detection of malformed association requests. Some wireless drivers used in access points do not
correctly parse the SSID information element tag contained in association request frames. A
malicious association request with a null SSID (that is, zero length SSID) can trigger a DoS or
potential code execution condition on the targeted device.
x-enumDescriptions.MALFORMED_FRAME_AUTH:
Detection of malformed authentication frames. Malformed 802.11 authentication frames that do not
conform to the specification can expose vulnerabilities in some drivers that have not implemented
proper error checking. This feature checks for unexpected values in an Authentication frame.
x-enumDescriptions.OVERFLOW_IE:
Detection of overflow Information Elements. Some wireless drivers used in access points do not
correctly parse the vendor-specific IE tags. A malicious association request sent to the AP
containing an IE with an inappropriate length (too long) can cause a DoS and potentially lead
to code execution. The association request must be sent after a successful 802.11 authentication
exchange.
x-enumDescriptions.OVERFLOW_EAPOL_KEY:
Detection of overflow EAPOL key requests. Some wireless drivers used in access points do not
correctly validate the EAPOL key fields. A malicious EAPOL-Key packet with an invalid advertised
length can trigger a DoS or possible code execution. This can only be achieved after a successful
802.11 association exchange.
x-enumDescriptions.BEACON_WRONG_CHANNEL:
Detection of beacons advertising the incorrect channel. In this type of attack, an intruder spoofs
a beacon packet on a channel that is different from that advertised in the beacon frame of the AP.
The Beacon wrong channel event is supported only on the 5 GHz band.
x-enumDescriptions.INVALID_MAC_OUI:
Checking of the first three bytes of a MAC address, known as the OUI,
assigned by the IEEE to known manufacturers. Often clients using a spoofed MAC address do not
use a valid OUI and instead use a randomly generated MAC address. Enabling MAC OUI checking
causes an alarm to be triggered if an unrecognized MAC address is in use.
x-enumDescriptions.GHOSTTUNNEL_SERVER_ATTACK:
Ghost tunnel server side attack detection. When enabled, the AP can identify
ghost tunnel attacks from connected servers and issue alerts.
x-enumDescriptions.WIFI_DIRECT_P2P_GROUPS:
Detection of WIFI-Direct P2P Groups. Wi-Fi Direct (P2P) allows devices with the appropriate
hardware to connect directly to each other via Wi-Fi without an intermediate access point.

items.description:
Specifies the policy for detecting wireless attacks on access points.
Each of these options contains several default levels that enable different sets of policies.
An administrator can customize enable or disable these options accordingly.

x-enumDescriptions.LOW:
Low infrastructure protection level, it includes:
Protect SSID—Valid SSID list should be auto-derived from AP configuration
Rogue Containment.
x-enumDescriptions.MEDIUM: Medium infrastructure protection level, it does not include more than low level.
x-enumDescriptions.HIGH:
High infrastructure protection level, it includes:
Protect from ad hoc Networks
Protect AP Impersonation
NOTE: Higher protection levels include the protection policies of the levels below them.
x-enumDescriptions.SSID: Protect SSID enforces that valid or protected SSIDs are used only by valid APs.
x-enumDescriptions.ROGUE_CONTAINMENT:
Controls Rogue APs. When rogue APs are detected, they are not automatically disabled.
This option automatically shuts down rogue APs. When this option is enabled, clients attempting
to associate to an AP classified as a rogue are disconnected through a DoS attack.
x-enumDescriptions.ADHOC_NETWORK: Protection from adhoc networks. When adhoc networks are detected, they are disabled using a DoS attack.
x-enumDescriptions.AP_IMPERSONATION:
Protection from AP impersonation attacks. When AP impersonation is detected,
both the legitimate and impersonating AP are disabled using a DoS attack.
x-enumDescriptions.WIFI_DIRECT_P2P_GROUPS:
Protection from WIFI-Direct P2P Groups. Wi-Fi Direct (P2P) allows devices with the appropriate
hardware to connect directly to each other via Wi-Fi without an intermediate access point.

items.description:
Specifies the policy for protecting access points from wireless attacks.
Each of these options contains several default levels that enable different sets of policies.
An administrator can customize enable or disable these options accordingly.

ghosttunnel-client.description:
Ghost tunnel attack is a backdoor transmission method that can be used in an isolated
environment. A ghost tunnel attack uses 802.11 probe request packets or beacon packets
to communicate with the host without establishing a Wi-Fi connection.

For the client-side ghost tunnel attack, the AP monitors the abnormal probe request
packets in the wireless environment. When a client is heard by the AP, it looks for
abnormal probe request packets from the client. The system reports a ghost tunnel detection
event with the client's MAC address when the alert criteria is met. If only abnormal probe
request packets are monitored and there is no matching client, then the reported event does
not contain the client's MAC address.

attack-interval.description: Time interval at which the packet count is checked for client side ghost tunnel attacks.

attack-threshold.description:
Number of abnormal probe request packets required to flag a ghost tunnel attack.
When the number of probe request packets that match the ghost tunnel attack exceed the threshold
within the defined attack interval, the event is flagged as a ghost tunnel attack.

quiet-time.description:
Time to wait before resuming ghost tunnel attack detection after an attack
is detected. This avoids flooding of event logs.

ghosttunnel-server.description:
Ghost tunnel attack is a backdoor transmission method that can be used in an isolated
environment. A ghost tunnel attack uses 802.11 probe request packets or beacon packets
to communicate with the host without establishing a Wi-Fi connection.

The server side of ghost tunnel uses beacon packets to send commands to the client and
the client sends probe-request automatically in response to the server's request, thereby
infecting the system. The server-side ghost tunnel attack detection system relies on
identifying abnormal beacon packets and flagging the attacking server.

attack-interval.description: Time interval at which the packet count is checked for ghost tunnel attacks from servers.

attack-threshold.description:
Number of abnormal beacon packets required to flag a ghost tunnel attack.
When the number of beacon packets that match the ghost tunnel attack rule exceed the threshold
within the defined attack interval, the event is flagged as a ghost tunnel attack.

quiet-time.description:
Time to wait before resuming ghost tunnel attack detection after an attack is detected.
This avoids flooding of event logs.

wired-containment.description: Prevents unauthorized wired stations from connecting to network.

enable.description:
Enables wired attacks.
Disable by default.

ap-mac-offset.description:
Wired containment to Rogue APs whose wired interface MAC address is offset by one from its BSSID.
Disable by default.

suspend-l3-rogue.description:
Identify and contain an AP with a preset wired MAC address that is different from
the BSSID of the AP if the MAC address that the AP provides to wireless clients as
the Gateway MAC is offset by one character from its wired MAC address.
Disable by default.

ap-max-unseen-timeout.description:
Ageout time for interfering AP in an unknown network. The interfering AP will be deleted
if it is not seen by the AP after the configured duration is elapsed. For interfering APs
operating in a different channel, the ageout time is twice the duration configured.

valid-ap-max-unseen-timeout.description:
Ageout time for valid AP entries in the Unknown Access Points Detected
table of the network. The entry of the valid AP will be deleted if it is not seen
by the AP after the configured duration is elapsed. For valid APs operating in a different
channel, the ageout time is twice the duration configured. The value is configured in seconds.

wireless-containment.description: Prevents unauthorized wireless stations from connecting to network.

x-enumDescriptions.TARPIT_ALL_STA:
Tarpit, a computer technique that purposefully delays incoming connections,
will handle all stations.

type.x-typeDescription: Different types in wireless or wired containment

deauth-reason.description: Deauth reason code of wireless containment, its value is defined in 802.11.

parse-adhoc-awdl-network.description:
Process frames from adhoc Apple Wireless Direct Link (AWDL) networks.
Disable by default.

x-enumDescriptions.HSRP:
HSRP, a Cisco-proprietary redundancy protocol, with the HSRP MAC
(Organizationally Unique Identifier) OUI 00:00:0c.
An OUI is a 24-bit number that uniquely identifies a vendor or manufacturer.
x-enumDescriptions.IANA: IANA allocates addresses under the IANA OUI (00-00-5E).
x-enumDescriptions.LOCAL_MAC: Locally administered MAC addresses starting with 02.

max-potential-stations.description: The max allowed potential stations, 512 by default.

max-monitored-aps.description: The max allowed AP to monitor, 0 by default.

wifi-direct-network-quiet-time.description:
Time to wait in seconds after detecting a WIFI Direct network, after which the check
can be resumed.

vendor-ie-exclusion.description:
Configures exclusions for IDS containment based on vendor specific IE information.
This feature allows APs to be exempted from containment even when the devices use
randomized MAC addresses. AP allows for a maximum of five vendor OUI and OUI types
to be defined for confinement exclusion.

oui.description: The Organizational Unique Identifier (OUI) of mac address.

type.description: Type of Organizational Unique Identifier (OUI) that is defined by vendor.

laa-counter-msg.description: Locally administratered address, which is also called random mac, counter parameters.

enable.description:
Enalbe Laa counter message.
Disable by default.

interval.description: Interval to report laa counter message.

wired-protection.description: Enables firewall settings to protect the network against wired attacks, such as ARP attacks or malformed DHCP packets.

drop-bad-arp.description:
Block and drop bad ARP request.
Disable by default.

fix-dhcp.description:
Fix malformed DHCP packets.
Disable by default.

poison-check.description:
Enable user alert about ARP. This triggers alerts when a known client spoofs the base MAC address.
Disable by default.

Successful200.description: Success response returned from the server.

Error400.description: Error details returned from the server.

message.example: Bad request. Invalid values supplied in request.

Error401.description: Error details returned from the server.

Error403.description: Error details returned from the server.

Error404.description: Error details returned from the server.

message.example: Not found. Yang / Corresponding Rule is missing.

Error406.description: Error details returned from the server.

Error408.description: Error details returned from the server.

Error412.description: Error details returned from the server.

Error429.description: Error details returned from the server.

Error500.description: Error details returned from the server.
